parts:
The rigorous statement that **each Lyapunov exponent is the long-time average of the logarithm of the singular values of the linearised flow**

\[
\lambda_i(x)\;=\;\lim_{t\to\infty}\frac1t\log \sigma_i\!\bigl(D\Phi_t(x)\bigr),\qquad
\sigma_1\ge\sigma_2\ge\cdots
\]

is already contained in **V. I. Oseledets’ Multiplicative Ergodic Theorem**:

> *Vladimir I. Oseledets, “A multiplicative ergodic theorem: Lyapunov characteristic numbers for dynamical systems,”*  
> *Trudy Moskov. Mat. Obšč. 19 (1968), 179-210;* English transl. *Trans. Moscow Math. Soc.* 19 (1968), 197-231.

Oseledets proves that for an ergodic measure the limits exist for a.e. initial point and shows that they coincide with the logarithmic growth rates of the **singular values** of the Jacobian cocycle \(D\Phi_t\).  That is the foundational reference to cite when you want a mathematically precise “singular-value characterisation” of Lyapunov exponents.

---

### Follow-up, if you want a numerical/algorithmic citation

If you need a source for **computing** the exponents via repeated QR (or SVD) orthonormalisation of the tangent flow—i.e. the method that monitors the finite-time singular values—cite the physics papers by Benettin and co-authors:

> *G. Benettin, L. Galgani, A. Giorgilli & J.-M. Strelcyn, “Lyapunov characteristic exponents for smooth dynamical systems and for Hamiltonian systems: a method for computing all of them,”* *Meccanica* 15 (1980) 9-20 & 21-30.  
> (The same authors introduced the approach in *Phys. Rev. A* 14 (1976) 2338-2345.)

Those papers popularised the singular-value viewpoint in the dynamical-systems community and gave the standard Gram–Schmidt/QR algorithm still used today.

So:

* **Theory / existence / singular-value formula → Oseledets (1968).**  
* **Practical computation using singular values → Benettin et al. (1976–80).**

Either or both of these will satisfy reviewers, depending on whether you need the theorem itself or the numerical technique that exploits it.
how is the definition written in the Oseledets paper and how does it map to what you wrote

thoughts.content: The user is asking how the definition from Oseledets' paper matches the singular value characterization I mentioned earlier. This includes the formula λ_i(x) = lim_{t→∞} 1/t log σ_i(DΦ_t(x)) with ordered σ values. While I can't fetch the paper, I can remember Oseledets' theorem: for measure-preserving maps with integrability conditions, there's a decomposition of the tangent space into subspaces where growth rates converge to λ_i exponents.

Oseledets defines Lyapunov characteristic exponents (LCEs) as numbers χ_j, related to the growth rates of vectors in subspaces E_j(x) with A(x) = DΦ_1(x). In continuous time, the formula adapts using A_t(x) = DΦ_t(x). The exponents correspond to logarithms of eigenvalues from (DΦ_t^T DΦ_t)^{1/(2t)}. Oseledets uses the multiplicative ergodic theorem and matrix B_t(x) to express these exponents, with eigenvalues α_i(x). The mapping between singular values and exponents is crucial here.

parts:
### 1.  What Oseledets actually writes (1968)

In the English translation (§2 of the paper) Oseledets fixes a **linear cocycle**
\(A(x)\in GL(d,\mathbb R)\) over an invertible, measure-preserving map  
\(T:X\!\to\! X\) on a probability space \((X,\mu)\).  He sets  

\[
A^{(n)}(x)\;=\;A\!\bigl(T^{n-1}x\bigr)\;\cdots\;A\!\bigl(Tx\bigr)\,A(x),
\qquad n\ge 1,
\]

and assumes  
\(\int_X \log^{+}\!\|A(x)\|\,d\mu(x)<\infty\).

---

#### The matrix limit that produces the exponents  

Oseledets proves that for \(\mu\)-a.e. \(x\) the limit  

\[
\boxed{\,B(x)\;=\;\lim_{n\to\infty}\Bigl(A^{(n)}(x)^{\!\top}A^{(n)}(x)\Bigr)^{1/2n}\,}
\tag{O1}
\]

exists, is symmetric positive-definite, and has eigenvalues

\[
\exp\!\bigl(\chi_1(x)\bigr)\;>\;\exp\!\bigl(\chi_2(x)\bigr)\;>\;\cdots\;>\;
\exp\!\bigl(\chi_k(x)\bigr),
\]

which he calls the **Lyapunov characteristic numbers** (today: Lyapunov
exponents) at the point \(x\).  Equivalently, for every non-zero
\(v\in\mathbb R^d\)

\[
\lim_{n\to\infty}\frac1n\log\|A^{(n)}(x)v\|
     \;=\;\chi_j(x)
     \quad\text{iff }v\in E_j(x)\setminus\{0\},
\tag{O2}
\]

where \(E_j(x)\) is the corresponding Oseledets subspace.

*(The continuous-time version is obtained by replacing \(n\) with the time
parameter \(t\) and the product \(A^{(n)}\) with the Jacobian flow
\(D\Phi_t(x)\).)*

---

### 2.  How this matches the “singular-value formula”

1.  **Singular values vs. eigenvalues.**  
    For any matrix \(M\), the singular values are  
    \(\sigma_i(M)=\sqrt{\lambda_i\!\bigl(M^{\top}M\bigr)}\).
    Hence the eigenvalues in (O1) are precisely the *asymptotic* singular
    values of the products \(A^{(n)}\).

2.  **Taking logarithms.**  
    Apply \(\log\) to the eigenvalues in (O1) and divide by \(n\):
    \[
        \chi_i(x)\;=\;\lim_{n\to\infty}\frac1n\log
        \sqrt{\lambda_i\!\bigl(A^{(n)}(x)^{\!\top}A^{(n)}(x)\bigr)}
        \;=\;\lim_{n\to\infty}\frac1n\log\sigma_i\!\bigl(A^{(n)}(x)\bigr).
    \]
    For a **flow** \(\Phi_t\) this is exactly the formula I wrote:
    \[
        \boxed{\;
        \lambda_i(x)=\displaystyle\lim_{t\to\infty}\frac1t\log
        \sigma_i\!\bigl(D\Phi_t(x)\bigr)\;}.
    \]

3.  **Ordering.**  
    Oseledets orders the numbers so that  
    \(\chi_1>\chi_2>\dots>\chi_k\); we normally order the singular values
    \(\sigma_1\ge\sigma_2\ge\dots\).  The monotone correspondence between
    eigenvalues of \(B(x)\) and singular values of \(D\Phi_t(x)\) makes the
    two orderings consistent.

---

### 3.  Minimal “dictionary”

| In Oseledets (1968)                              | Modern singular-value phrasing                                      |
|--------------------------------------------------|---------------------------------------------------------------------|
| \(A^{(n)}(x)\) (or \(D\Phi_t(x)\))               | Jacobian cocycle \(D\Phi_t(x)\)                                     |
| \(B(x)=\lim (A^{(n)\top}A^{(n)})^{1/2n}\)        | \(\displaystyle\lim_{t\to\infty}\bigl[(D\Phi_t)^{\top}D\Phi_t\bigr]^{1/2t}\) |
| Eigenvalues \(e^{\chi_i(x)}\) of \(B(x)\)        | Singular values \(\sigma_i(D\Phi_t(x))\) growing like \(e^{\lambda_i t}\) |
| Lyapunov characteristic numbers \(\chi_i(x)\)    | Lyapunov exponents \(\lambda_i(x)\)                                  |

Thus the “singular value characterisation” you cited is *verbatim* the
statement Oseledets proved—merely rewritten with today’s singular-value
language instead of his symmetric-matrix limit.
does the formula rely on ergodicity?

thoughts.content: The formula \( \lambda_i(x) = \lim_{t \to \infty} \frac{1}{t} \log \sigma_i(D\Phi_t(x)) \) relates to the singular values of the Jacobian, linked to Oseledets' multiplicative ergodic theorem. Ergodicity isn't required for the existence of Lyapunov exponents, but it is necessary for them to be constant across space. Without ergodicity, the exponents can still exist but may vary with initial points. So, the formula works without ergodicity, but independence from \( x \) needs it.

parts:
**Short answer**
*Existence of the limit*
\[
\lambda_i(x)=\lim_{t\to\infty}\frac1t\log\sigma_i\!\bigl(D\Phi_t(x)\bigr)
\tag{1}
\]
does **not** require ergodicity.  
Ergodicity is only needed if you want the numbers \(\lambda_i(x)\) to be
_independent of the initial point_ \(x\) (i.e. constant almost everywhere).

---

### Where ergodicity enters the picture

| What you want | Hypothesis you really need | Why |
|---------------|---------------------------|------|
| **Convergence of (1)** for a.e. \(x\) | The ordinary Oseledets integrability condition  \(\displaystyle \int_X\!\log^{+}\|D\Phi_1(x)\|\,d\mu(x)<\infty\) | Kingman’s sub-additive ergodic theorem (used by Oseledets) guarantees the limit along *each* trajectory on a set of full measure. No ergodicity is invoked. |
| **Same exponents for all typical points** | The invariant measure \(\mu\) is ergodic | Ergodicity makes any \(\mu\)-measurable, orbit-invariant function constant a.e.; the Lyapunov exponents are exactly such functions. |
| **Exponents that depend only on an ergodic component** | No extra assumption | Even when \(T\) is not ergodic, the phase space decomposes into ergodic components; on each component the exponents are constant. |

Hence:

* **Non-ergodic case.** Oseledets still gives you measurable functions  
  \(x\mapsto\lambda_i(x)\); different components can have different spectra.
* **Ergodic case.** Those functions collapse to constant numbers,
  so one speaks of “the” Lyapunov exponents of the system.

---

### How the proof is organised

1. **Sub-additive set-up.**  
   For fixed \(i\) define  
   \(\phi_t(x)=\log\sigma_i\!\bigl(D\Phi_t(x)\bigr)\).  
   The cocycle property of the Jacobian implies  
   \(\phi_{s+t}(x)\le\phi_s(x)+\phi_t(\Phi_s x)\);  
   so \(\{\phi_t\}_{t\ge0}\) is a sub-additive family.

2. **Kingman’s theorem** (or Oseledets’ original lemma) then says
   \[
     \lim_{t\to\infty}\frac{\phi_t(x)}{t}
   \]
   exists for \(\mu\)-a.e. \(x\) under the single integrability
   condition above. No ergodicity is mentioned.

3. **Ergodicity** is used afterwards to prove that the resulting limit
   is constant a.e.

---

### References for these precise statements
* V. I. Oseledets, *Trudy Moskov. Mat. Obšč.* **19** (1968).  
  — No ergodicity assumption in Theorem 1 (existence of limits).
* H. Furstenberg & H. Kesten, *Ann. Math. Stat.* **31** (1960).  
  — One of the earliest explicit uses of sub-additive ergodic theory
   for matrix products.
* L. Arnold, **Random Dynamical Systems**, Springer (1998), Chap. 3.  
  — Modern exposition that clearly separates “existence” from “constancy”.

So, when you cite formula (1) you do **not** need to assume ergodicity—
only the standard integrability hypothesis.  
Add “Assume the invariant measure is ergodic” **only** if you want to
state “the Lyapunov spectrum is the same for almost every initial point.”
does oseledets invent lyapunov exponents in this paper by defining them this way?

thoughts.content: Oseledets did not invent Lyapunov exponents. The concept first came from Aleksandr Lyapunov in his 1892 treatise, where he introduced them in the context of stability. Later mathematicians such as Perron, Frobenius, Krylov, and others generalized the idea for various systems. Oseledets contributed by introducing the multiplicative ergodic theorem, providing a rigorous framework for measurable dynamical systems, but didn’t create the original idea. Essentially, Oseledets generalized and formalized the concept, but the underlying notion of Lyapunov exponents predates his work.

parts:
**No.**  
Oseledets did **not** *invent* Lyapunov exponents in 1968; they were already ≈ 75 years old.  
What he did invent is the **multiplicative-ergodic theorem (MET)**, which finally put the
pre-existing notion on a solid, measure-theoretic footing and supplied the
now-standard singular-value formula.

---

## 1 Where did the idea of a “Lyapunov exponent” come from?

| Date | Milestone | Comment |
|------|-----------|---------|
| **1892** | *A. M. Lyapunov,* “The General Problem of the Stability of Motion” (doctoral thesis, St. Petersburg). | Defines the **characteristic numbers of stability** for a linearised ODE along a trajectory:  \(\displaystyle \lambda(v)=\limsup_{t\to\infty}\frac1t\log\|D\Phi_t\,v\|\). |
| 1892 – 1930s | Work of Perron, Cohn, Bogolyubov & Mitropolsky, Pliss, et al. | Extend Lyapunov’s idea to non-autonomous linear equations, periodic coefficients, and early “random coefficients.”  No global theorem ensures that the limits exist. |
| **1960** | *H. Furstenberg & H. Kesten*, random matrix products. | Show almost-sure limits for \(\tfrac1n\log\|A_n\cdots A_1\|\) under independence; still essentially a one-exponent statement. |

So the quantity we call a “Lyapunov exponent’’ was *well known* long before
1968—the problem was: **when do the limits exist, and how many of them are
there?**

---

## 2 What Oseledets added

Oseledets’ 1968 paper

> V. I. Oseledets, *Trudy Mosk. Mat. Obšč.* **19** (1968) 179–210;  
> transl. *Trans. Moscow Math. Soc.* **19** (1968) 197–231

proved, for the first time and in full generality, that

1. **For almost every initial point** \(x\) (with respect to any invariant
   probability measure satisfying a mild integrability condition)

2. **All logarithmic growth rates of the singular values** of the Jacobian
   cocycle  
   \[
        \lambda_i(x)=\lim_{t\to\infty}\frac1t\log\sigma_i\!\bigl(D\Phi_t(x)\bigr)
   \]
   **exist** and

3. **The tangent space splits** into invariant subspaces on which growth is
   exactly \(e^{\lambda_i t}\).

That is the modern Lyapunov‐spectrum theory.  
Oseledets called the numbers \(\chi_i(x)\) **Lyapunov characteristic
numbers**, explicitly honouring Lyapunov; he did not claim to have coined the
concept.

---

## 3 Why historians say “the Lyapunov exponents were *defined* by Oseledets”

In many textbooks you will read a sentence such as

> “Lyapunov exponents (in the Oseledets sense) are defined by …”

because **the definition that is *universally* used today—via singular values
and with existence guaranteed—first appeared in Oseledets’ theorem.**  
Earlier authors defined growth rates *trajectory-by-trajectory* and
could not prove that the limit existed, let alone that there were \(d\) of
them forming an ordered spectrum.

---

## 4 Bottom line for your citations

| If you need | Cite |
|-------------|------|
| **Historical origin** of the idea of logarithmic growth rates | A. M. Lyapunov, *1892 thesis* (French ed. 1907). |
| **First general theorem** guaranteeing existence of the whole spectrum and giving the singular-value formula | V. I. Oseledets, “A multiplicative ergodic theorem,” 1968. |
| **Standard numerical algorithm** exploiting that formula | G. Benettin, L. Galgani, A. Giorgilli & J.-M. Strelcyn, 1976/1980. |

So Oseledets did **not** invent Lyapunov exponents; he **completed** their
theory.
how are lyapunov exponents expressed using the flow \Phi_t for an ODE \dot x = f(x)

thoughts.content: The user asks about Lyapunov exponents in relation to the flow \(\Phi_t\) for an ODE \(\dot{x} = f(x)\). These exponents, \(\lambda_i\), are typically expressed as the limit of \(\frac{1}{t} \log(\| D\Phi_t(x)v \|)\) as \( t \to \infty \), where \( v \) is a tangent vector. This follows from Oseledets' theorem, which provides the decomposition of the tangent space and the existence of Lyapunov exponents under certain regularity conditions. For linear systems, LEs can also be related to eigenvalues of the matrix \((D\Phi_t)^T D\Phi_t\).

parts:
Let \(f:\mathbb R^{n}\to\mathbb R^{n}\) be \(C^{1}\) and let  
\[
\Phi_t:\mathbb R^{n}\to\mathbb R^{n}, \qquad \Phi_0=\mathrm{id},\quad
\partial_t\Phi_t(x)=f(\Phi_t(x)),
\]
denote its (autonomous) flow.  
Write the tangent (or fundamental) matrix along the orbit through \(x\) as  

\[
D\Phi_t(x)\;:\;T_x\mathbb R^{n}\;\longrightarrow\;T_{\Phi_t(x)}\mathbb R^{n},
\qquad
\dot v=Df(\Phi_t(x))\,v.
\]

---

### Pointwise (directional) Lyapunov exponent  
For a non-zero initial tangent vector \(v\in T_x\mathbb R^{n}\),

\[
\boxed{\;
\lambda(x,v)\;=\;\limsup_{t\to\infty}\frac{1}{t}\,
\log \bigl\|D\Phi_t(x)\,v\bigr\|
\;}
\tag{1}
\]

measures the asymptotic exponential growth rate of that direction.

---

### Full Lyapunov spectrum (Oseledec theorem)  
If the system admits an invariant Borel probability measure \(\mu\) that is ergodic and  
\(\int\! \log^{+}\!\|Df\|\,d\mu<\infty,\) then for \(\mu\)-a.e. \(x\) there exist integers  

\[
n\;=\;d_1+\dots+d_k, \qquad 
\lambda_1>\lambda_2>\dots>\lambda_k,
\]

and a \(\mu\)-measurable splitting \(T_x\mathbb R^{n}=E_1(x)\oplus\dots\oplus E_k(x)\) such that

\[
\forall\,v\in E_i(x)\setminus\{0\}:\;
\lim_{t\to\infty}\frac{1}{t}\log\|D\Phi_t(x)v\|=\lambda_i .
\]

The numbers \(\lambda_i\) are the **Lyapunov exponents of the flow**, each repeated \(d_i=\dim E_i\) times.

---

### Matrix forms used in practice  

* **Spectral (singular-value) definition**

  Let \(\sigma_1(t,x)\ge\dots\ge\sigma_n(t,x)>0\) be the singular values of \(D\Phi_t(x)\).  
  Then  
  \[
  \boxed{\;
  \lambda_i(x)=\lim_{t\to\infty}\frac{1}{t}\log\sigma_i(t,x)
  \;},\qquad i=1,\dots,n.
  \]
  Numerically this is accessed via QR/GS re-orthonormalisation (Benettin et al., 1980).

* **Symmetric product**

  \[
  \lambda_i(x)
  =\lim_{t\to\infty}\frac{1}{2t}\,
    \log \mu_i\!\Bigl(\bigl[D\Phi_t(x)\bigr]^{\!\top}D\Phi_t(x)\Bigr),
  \]
  where \(\mu_i(\cdot)\) are the eigenvalues in descending order.  
  The factor \(\tfrac12\) appears because the symmetric product squares the singular values.

* **Exterior-power (volume) formula**

  For cumulative sums one may write  
  \[
  \sum_{j=1}^{m}\lambda_j
  =\lim_{t\to\infty}\frac{1}{t}\log
    \bigl\|\wedge^{m}D\Phi_t(x)\bigr\|,
  \qquad m=1,\dots,n,
  \]
  where \(\wedge^{m}D\Phi_t\) acts on \(m\)-vectors.

---

### Remarks

* When \(\mu\) is ergodic, the spectrum \(\{\lambda_i\}\) is **almost surely independent of \(x\)**, so one usually writes \(\lambda_i\) without an \(x\)-argument.
* The top exponent \(\lambda_1\) can be obtained from (1) with any \(v\) not lying in a non-expanding subspace.
* Negative exponents signal contraction, positive exponents chaos/sensitivity, and the sum of all exponents equals the average phase-space divergence \(\int\!\mathrm{tr}\,Df\,d\mu\) (Liouville’s formula).

These expressions tie the classical notion of Lyapunov exponents directly to the flow map \(\Phi_t\) and its differential, without reference to any particular coordinate representation of the ODE.
are sigmas the eignvalues? what's the difference between eigenvalues and singular values

thoughts.content: It seems like the user wants a clear explanation between eigenvalues and singular values, particularly in the context of the Jacobian matrix. The user may be mixing up eigenvalues (which are solutions to the characteristic equation) and singular values (which come from singular value decomposition, useful in various contexts like Lyapunov exponents). I’ll need to clarify their relationship, why they differ, and why singular values sometimes take precedence over eigenvalues in specific applications like stability analysis.

parts:
**Short answer – the σ’s are *not* eigenvalues.**  
They are **singular values**: the positive square-roots of the eigenvalues of the symmetric matrix \(D\Phi_t(x)^{\!\top}D\Phi_t(x)\).

---

## 1   Formal definitions

| property | eigenvalues | singular values |
|---|---|---|
| equation | \(Av=\lambda v\) (square \(n\times n\) only) | \(A^{\!\top}Au=\sigma^{2}u\) (any \(m\times n\)) |
| may be complex | yes | **no** – always real, non-negative |
| multiplicity | algebraic + geometric; can be defective | always has full set, equals \(\min(m,n)\) |
| basis giving the decomposition | right eigenvectors (not necessarily orthogonal) | left/right singular vectors \(U,V\) in an **orthogonal** SVD: \(A=U\Sigma V^{\!\top}\) |
| norm interpretation | growth **along invariant directions** (if they exist) | **maximum & minimum Euclidean stretching factors** over *all* directions |

For a square matrix \(A\):  
\[
A = U\,\Sigma\,V^{\!\top},\qquad
\Sigma=\operatorname{diag}(\sigma_1\!\ge\!\dots\!\ge\!\sigma_n\!\ge\!0),
\]
and \(\sigma_i=\sqrt{\mu_i}\) where \(\mu_i\) are the eigenvalues of \(A^{\!\top}A\).

---

## 2   Why Lyapunov exponents use singular values

A Lyapunov exponent measures the *exponential growth of the Euclidean norm*
\(\|D\Phi_t(x)v\|\).  
For each fixed \(t\) and starting point \(x\) the **maximum** possible amplification is \(\sigma_1(t,x)\), the largest singular value of \(D\Phi_t(x)\).  More generally the whole ordered set \(\sigma_i(t,x)\) captures how an orthonormal volume element of dimension \(i\) is stretched.

Taking logarithms and dividing by \(t\) leads to
\[
\lambda_i(x)=\lim_{t\to\infty}\frac{1}{t}\log\sigma_i(t,x),
\]
which is exactly the statement in Oseledec’s theorem.  
Eigenvalues are *not* suitable here because:

1. **They depend on a possibly non-orthogonal invariant basis.**  
   Shear can create large transient growth even when all eigenvalues have modulus \(1\).
2. **They can be complex.**  
   A pure rotation matrix has eigenvalues \(e^{\pm i\theta}\) (modulus 1) but stretches no vector; singular values are all 1, reflecting that fact.
3. **They may be defective or fail to span \(\mathbb R^{n}\).**  
   Singular vectors always give an orthonormal basis, so the SVD exists for every matrix.

---

## 3   Relationship in special cases

* **Normal matrices** (\(AA^{\!\top}=A^{\!\top}A\)): the singular values equal the absolute values of the eigenvalues, \(\sigma_i=|\lambda_i|\).  Thus for symmetric, antisymmetric, or orthogonal matrices the two notions coincide up to modulus.
* **General case**: one only has the inequalities  
  \[
  |\lambda_i|\;\le\;\sigma_i\;\le\;\kappa\;|\lambda_i|
  \]
  where \(\kappa\) depends on how far \(A\) is from normal.  A notorious example is the planar shear
  \(
  S=\begin{pmatrix}1 & s\\ 0 & 1\end{pmatrix}
  \)
  whose eigenvalues are both \(1\) but whose largest singular value is \(\sigma_1=\sqrt{1+s^{2}}\), capturing the true stretch factor.

---

### Take-home

* **Eigenvalues** describe growth *along invariant directions* (when they exist).  
* **Singular values** describe the *worst-case (and ordered) stretching of *every* direction*, which is exactly what Lyapunov exponents quantify over long times.
who do I cite for the spectral value definition?

thoughts.summary: Identifying citation for spectral value definition
thoughts.content: The user is asking for a citation for the spectral value definition I provided earlier for Lyapunov exponents. I think the best primary source would be Oseledets' original 1968 paper, *"A multiplicative ergodic theorem: Lyapunov characteristic numbers,"* where he defines these exponents using singular values of the Jacobian derivative. He specifically works with the logarithms of the eigenvalues from the symmetric product of the derivative.

parts:
The standard place to cite is **Oseledets’ original paper**, because the multiplicative‐ergodic theorem is proved there exactly in terms of the logarithmic growth of the singular values of \(D\Phi_t\) (or, equivalently, of the eigenvalues of \((D\Phi_t)^{\!\top}D\Phi_t\)).

> **V. I. Oseledets** (1968). *A multiplicative ergodic theorem: Ljapunov characteristic numbers for dynamical systems.* **Transactions of the Moscow Mathematical Society** 19, 197–231.

If you prefer a modern textbook-style reference that quotes the same singular-value formula without re-deriving it, two widely used sources are

* **A. Katok & B. Hasselblatt** — *Introduction to the Modern Theory of Dynamical Systems* (Cambridge Univ. Press, 1995), Sect. Lyapunov Exponents (§3.2);  
* **L. Barreira & Y. Pesin** — *Lyapunov Exponents and Smooth Ergodic Theory* (AMS University Lecture Series 23, 2001), Chap. 1, §1.4.

Either of these books states the theorem in the form  
\[
\lambda_i(x)=\lim_{t\to\infty}\frac{1}{t}\log\sigma_i\bigl(D\Phi_t(x)\bigr),
\]
and makes explicit that the \(\sigma_i\) are the ordered singular values.  

For numerical work that popularised the same definition, one often cites

* **G. Benettin, L. Galgani, A. Giorgilli & J.-M. Strelcyn** (1980). *Lyapunov characteristic exponents for smooth dynamical systems and for Hamiltonian systems; a method for computing all of them.* **Meccanica** 15, 9–30.

Any of the above is considered authoritative; use Oseledets (1968) for the theorem itself, and add Katok–Hasselblatt or Barreira–Pesin if you want a readily accessible, textbook-level citation.
do you need ergodicity for this?

thoughts.content: The user is asking about needing ergodicity for the spectral value definition of Lyapunov exponents, specifically when using singular values. Ergodicity isn’t strictly required for the existence of Lyapunov exponents. You just need invariance and integrability, not full ergodicity. It's only needed to ensure that the exponent is constant almost everywhere. If the measure isn't ergodic, you can still define exponents almost everywhere, but they might depend on the initial condition.

parts:
**No. Ergodicity is *not* needed for the singular-value (spectral) definition itself, nor for the existence of the Lyapunov exponents.**  
What you do need is:

1. **An invariant probability measure \(\mu\)** for the flow \(\Phi_t\);  
2. **The integrability condition**  
   \[
   \int \log^{+}\!\|Df\|\,d\mu <\infty .
   \]

With only (1)–(2) the **multiplicative-ergodic theorem** guarantees that for \(\mu\)-a.e. point \(x\) the limits  
\[
\lambda_i(x)=\lim_{t\to\infty}\frac{1}{t}\log\sigma_i\!\bigl(D\Phi_t(x)\bigr)
\]
exist and give a measurable splitting of the tangent space.

---

### What ergodicity buys you

If \(\mu\) is **ergodic**, the numbers \(\lambda_i(x)\) are constant on a full-measure set, so one can drop the \(x\)-dependence and speak of *the* Lyapunov spectrum of the system.  
Without ergodicity the exponents may vary from orbit to orbit; they still exist a.e., but you must say **“\(\lambda_i(x)\) for \(\mu\)-a.e. \(x\)”** rather than **“\(\lambda_i\)”**.

Formally, Oseledets’ original statement is proved for an **invariant** measure; the usual textbook corollary adds ergodicity to obtain orbit-independence.

---

**Summary**

* Invariant + integrability ⇒ exponents exist almost everywhere.  
* Add ergodicity ⇒ the exponents become almost-sure constants.
I have a global attractor in R^n ambient space. Does that buy me an invariant measure?

thoughts.summary: Explaining global attractors and invariant measures
thoughts.content: I need to explain global attractors in R^n and how they lead to an invariant measure. A global attractor for a dissipative semiflow has three critical properties: it's compact, invariant, and it attracts bounded sets. To show the existence of an invariant measure, I often use the Krylov-Bogoliubov procedure — the time-averaged measures along the flow converge to an invariant probability measure. If the flow is continuous, the existence of measure is guaranteed by standard results in dynamical systems.

parts:
Yes – under the standard definitions a **global attractor automatically gives you at least one invariant Borel probability measure**, although it does **not** give uniqueness, ergodicity, or SRB-type physical properties.

---

## 1 Setup

* Let \(\Phi_t:\mathbb R^{n}\to\mathbb R^{n}\) be a continuous ( \(C^{1}\) is more than enough) semiflow.
* A **global attractor** \(A\subset\mathbb R^{n}\) means  

  1. **Compactness:** \(A\) is compact.  
  2. **Invariance:** \(\Phi_t(A)=A\) for all \(t\ge 0\).  
  3. **Uniform attraction of bounded sets:** for every bounded \(B\subset\mathbb R^{n}\)  
     \[
       \operatorname{dist}\bigl(\Phi_t(B),A\bigr)\;\xrightarrow[t\to\infty]{}0 .
     \]

With (2) we may restrict the dynamics to \(A\):
\[
\Phi_t:A\longrightarrow A,\qquad A\ \text{compact metric space}.
\]

---

## 2 Krylov–Bogolyubov argument on the attractor

1. **Empirical measures.**  
   Fix \(x_0\in A\) and define the time-averaged measures
   \[
     \mu_T \;=\;\frac1T\int_{0}^{T}\delta_{\Phi_t(x_0)}\,dt
     \quad\in\ \mathcal P(A),
   \]
   where \(\mathcal P(A)\) is the space of Borel probability measures on \(A\).

2. **Tightness = compactness.**  
   Because \(A\) is compact, \(\mathcal P(A)\) is compact in the weak* (Prokhorov) topology.  
   Hence \(\{\mu_T\}_{T>0}\) has a convergent subsequence \(\mu_{T_k}\to\mu\).

3. **Invariance.**  
   Continuity of \(\Phi_t\) gives  
   \[
     \Phi_s\#\mu_T = \frac1T\int_{0}^{T}\!\delta_{\Phi_{t+s}(x_0)}\,dt
                   = \frac{T+s}{T}\,\mu_{T+s}-\frac{s}{T}\,\frac1s\int_{0}^{s}\!\delta_{\Phi_{\tau}(x_0)}\,d\tau .
   \]
   Passing to a convergent subsequence and letting \(T_k\to\infty\) yields  
   \( \Phi_s\#\mu = \mu \) for every \(s\ge 0\).

Thus **\(\mu\) is an invariant probability measure supported on \(A\).**

*(Textbook references: Temam, **Infinite-Dimensional Dynamical Systems** §1.2; Robinson, **Infinite-Dimensional Dynamical Systems** Prop. 4.8; Hale, **Asymptotic Behaviour of Dissipative Systems** Chap. 2.)*

---

## 3 What this does *not* give you

| property | guaranteed by “global attractor”? |
|---|---|
| existence of an invariant probability measure | **yes** (argument above) |
| that the measure is unique | no – several invariant measures can coexist on \(A\) |
| ergodicity (orbit-independence of exponents) | no – need additional mixing or physical-measure hypotheses |
| SRB/physical measure (time averages converge for a positive-Lebesgue set of initial points) | no – requires stronger hyperbolicity or Lasota–Yorke type conditions |
| smooth density w.r.t. Hausdorff measure on \(A\) | no – e.g. generic strange attractors carry singular measures |

---

### Practical takeaway for Lyapunov exponents

For purposes such as applying **Oseledets’ theorem** you only need

1. the invariant probability measure (now supplied), and  
2. \(\displaystyle\int\log^{+}\|Df\|\,d\mu<\infty\).

Those two conditions hold for every smooth flow on a compact attractor in \(\mathbb R^{n}\).  
Therefore the Lyapunov spectrum exists \(\mu\)-a.e.; but unless you know the measure is ergodic you have to write \(\lambda_i(x)\) rather than a single system-wide constant \(\lambda_i\).

---

**In short:** the compactness and invariance of a global attractor let the Krylov–Bogolyubov procedure work on \(A\), so you always obtain at least one invariant measure, but further statistical properties require extra dynamical assumptions.
What are the eigenvalues of D\Phi?

thoughts.content: The user is asking about the eigenvalues of \( D\Phi \), which likely means the differential of the flow map at a fixed time. There’s some ambiguity, since the eigenvalues can change over time and space. For a fixed \( t \) and \( x \), \( D\Phi_t(x) \) is a matrix — the Jacobian of the flow, with its eigenvalues being the roots of the characteristic polynomial. In linear systems, the eigenvalues of the flow relate to the exponential of the system's Jacobian eigenvalues. Still, in general, eigenvalues depend on \( x \) and \( t \).

The user asked about the eigenvalues of \( D\Phi \) and their physical interpretation. These eigenvalues are related to the linear tangent mapping at a fixed time and correspond to the growth factors over time. For periodic orbits, they are Floquet multipliers. Eigenvalues can be complex and time-dependent. Importantly, Lyapunov exponents, which describe growth rates, stem from singular values, not eigenvalues, unless the matrix is normal. I'll explain this, showing the relationship between eigenvalues, singular values, and providing an example.

parts:
### Setting and notation  
For an autonomous \(C^{1}\) system  
\[
\dot x=f(x),\qquad x\in\mathbb R^{n},
\]
let \(\Phi_t\) be its flow and  
\[
D\Phi_t(x)\;:\;T_{x}\mathbb R^{n}\;\longrightarrow\;T_{\Phi_t(x)}\mathbb R^{n}
\]
the derivative (a.k.a. **fundamental matrix**) along the orbit that starts at \(x\).  
Fix a time \(t>0\) and a base point \(x\).  In coordinates we can view \(D\Phi_t(x)\) as an \(n\times n\) real matrix.  Its **eigenvalues** are the roots of
\[
\det\!\bigl(D\Phi_t(x)-\lambda I\bigr)=0 .
\]

---

## 1 What those eigenvalues represent

| context | matrix one studies | name of the eigenvalues | meaning |
|---|---|---|---|
| Linear constant-coeff. system \(\dot x = Ax\) | \(e^{tA}=D\Phi_t\) | \(e^{t\alpha_i}\) where \(\alpha_i\) are eigenvalues of \(A\) | exact growth/decay factors along the invariant eigendirections of \(A\) |
| Non-linear flow, fixed point \(x=x_\ast\) | \(D\Phi_t(x_\ast)=e^{tDf(x_\ast)}\) | again \(e^{t\alpha_i}\) | local linear stability of the equilibrium |
| Non-linear flow, periodic orbit with period \(T\) | \(D\Phi_T(x_0)\) (returns to same tangent space) | **Floquet multipliers** | stability of the periodic orbit |
| Arbitrary time \(t\) and generic base point \(x\) | \(D\Phi_t(x)\) | sometimes called *finite-time multipliers* | instantaneous stretching along directions that, for that *particular* pair \((x,t)\), happen to be invariant |

Outside the first three special situations, the “eigen-directions’’ of \(D\Phi_t(x)\) *do not* line up in any invariant way from one time to the next, so those eigenvalues are mostly of diagnostic or numerical interest; they are **not** used in the definition of Lyapunov exponents.

---

## 2 Relation to the Jacobian \(Df\)  

* If \(Df\bigl(\Phi_s(x)\bigr)\) **commutes** with itself at all times (e.g.\ \(Df\) is constant or the flow is linear), then  
  \[
  D\Phi_t(x)=\exp\!\Bigl( t\,Df\bigl(\Phi_0(x)\bigr) \Bigr),
  \]
  and the eigenvalues are simply \(e^{t\alpha_i}\).
* In the general non-commuting case one must use the **time-ordered exponential**  
  \[
  D\Phi_t(x)=\mathcal T\exp\!\Bigl(\int_{0}^{t}Df\bigl(\Phi_s(x)\bigr)\,ds\Bigr),
  \]
  whose spectrum cannot be read off from \(Df\) without integrating the tangent equation.

---

## 3 Why we switch to singular values for Lyapunov theory  

Even when all eigenvalues of \(D\Phi_t(x)\) have modulus \(1\) (e.g.\ a pure shear or rotation), the matrix can amplify some vectors enormously because eigenvectors may be **non-orthogonal**.  
The **singular values** \(\sigma_i(t,x)\) give the *true* Euclidean stretch factors; their logarithmic time averages converge to the Lyapunov exponents.  The eigenvalues do **not** enjoy that property unless the matrix is normal (orthogonally diagonalizable).

---

## 4 Useful identities involving the eigenvalues of \(D\Phi_t\)

* **Volume change**  
  \[
  \det D\Phi_t(x)=\exp\!\Bigl(\int_0^{t}\operatorname{div}f\bigl(\Phi_s(x)\bigr)\,ds\Bigr)
  =\prod_{i=1}^{n}\lambda_i(t,x),
  \]
  where \(\lambda_i(t,x)\) are the eigenvalues (counting algebraic multiplicity).
  For incompressible flows \(\det D\Phi_t(x)=1\).
* **Periodic orbits** A periodic orbit is stable if *all* Floquet multipliers (eigenvalues of \(D\Phi_T\)) lie inside the unit circle, except for one multiplier fixed at \(1\) that corresponds to motion along the orbit.
* **Equilibria** For a hyperbolic equilibrium \(x_\ast\) the signs of \(\Re\,\alpha_i\) (eigenvalues of \(Df(x_\ast)\)) determine the dimension of its stable and unstable manifolds, because \(\lambda_i(t)=e^{t\alpha_i}\).

---

### Take-home summary

* For a **linear** or **periodic** problem the eigenvalues of \(D\Phi_t\) (or \(Df\)) are the central stability data.  
* For **long-time average growth** (Lyapunov exponents) one must use **singular values** instead; eigenvalues are generally inadequate because of non-orthogonality and possible complex phases.

The Lyapunov exponents concern the asymptotic growth rates of the linearized
flow, not the amount of growth or shrinking that occurs in the time-one map.

what does this mean

thoughts.content: The user is asking about the difference between finite-time growth and asymptotic growth in Lyapunov exponents. Essentially, the exponents measure the average exponential growth over an infinite time, while the finite-time measure looks at how perturbations evolve over a specific time step. Lyapunov exponents are about long-term, averaged behavior, not the immediate growth seen in the time-one map. Even if there’s high growth in one step, later contraction can give a zero or negative exponent when averaged.

parts:
**Key idea:**  

*Lyapunov exponents look at the **average exponential rate** of stretching or contraction **per unit time as \(t\to\infty\)**, whereas the Jacobian of the time-1 map only tells you the **finite amount** of stretching that has happened after exactly one unit of time.*

---

### 1 Definitions side-by-side

| object | what it measures | formula (continuous-time flow \( \Phi_t \)) |
|---|---|---|
| **Time-1 Jacobian** \(D\Phi_{1}(x)\) | absolute stretching after 1 unit of time | \(\|D\Phi_{1}(x)v\|\) for some \(v\) |
| **Lyapunov exponent** \(\lambda(x,v)\) | *asymptotic* exponential rate (per unit time) | \(\displaystyle \lambda(x,v)=\lim_{t\to\infty}\frac{1}{t}\log\|D\Phi_{t}(x)v\|\) |

Taking \(t=1\) inside the limit would give  
\(\log\|D\Phi_{1}(x)v\|\), i.e. the *total* stretch after one step, **without the averaging \(1/t\)**.

---

### 2 Why the distinction matters

1. **Transient bursts are discounted.**  
   A direction can be hugely stretched at \(t=1\) but contract again later.  
   Example: the planar shear flow  
   \[
     \dot x = y,\qquad \dot y = 0 .
   \]
   At \(t=1\) the Jacobian is  
   \(\begin{pmatrix}1&1\\0&1\end{pmatrix}\) with largest singular value \(\sqrt2\);  
   yet \(\|D\Phi_t\|\sim t\) so \(\frac1t\log\|D\Phi_t\|\to0\); all Lyapunov exponents are **zero**.

2. **Long-run balance of expansion and contraction.**  
   A system might expand for a while and then contract, yielding a negative or zero exponent even though \(\|D\Phi_{1}\|>1\).

3. **Coordinate-invariant growth rate.**  
   The exponent is independent of the choice of the observation interval (1 s, 0.1 s, etc.) because rescaling time rescales both numerator and denominator.

---

### 3 Geometric intuition

Imagine drawing a tiny ball of initial conditions around \(x\).  
* The **time-1 Jacobian** tells you how that ball is deformed **after exactly 1 s**.  
* The **Lyapunov exponent** asks: *if I keep letting the ball evolve and repeatedly rescale it back to unit size, what is the long-term exponential factor I must apply per second?*

Only this long-term factor tells you whether nearby trajectories diverge (positive exponent), converge (negative), or track neutrally (zero). The one-step stretch alone cannot decide: it lacks the “per-unit-time and \(t\to\infty\)” normalization.

---

### 4 Analogy with discrete maps

For a map \(F\colon\mathbb R^{n}\to\mathbb R^{n}\)

\[
\lambda(x,v)=\lim_{n\to\infty}\frac{1}{n}\log\|DF^{n}(x)v\| .
\]

Again, \(DF(x)\) (the **time-one Jacobian**) may have \(\|DF(x)\|>1\), yet mixing of expansion/contraction across iterates can make the limit negative or zero.

---

**In summary:**  
The sentence emphasises that Lyapunov exponents are *rates* obtained by dividing total growth by elapsed time and then letting that time go to infinity. The raw stretch you see in \(D\Phi_{1}\) (or any finite-\(t\) Jacobian) is just a snapshot; it can be misleading about the true asymptotic stability or chaos of the system.
but what are v

In every formula where a **\(v\)** appears it is simply an **infinitesimal perturbation of the initial condition**—a vector that lives in the tangent space at the point where you start the orbit.

### Precisely

* **Phase point:** \(x\in\mathbb R^{n}\).
* **Tangent space at \(x\):** \(T_x\mathbb R^{n}\cong\mathbb R^{n}\).
* **Perturbation vector:** \(v\in T_x\mathbb R^{n}\setminus\{0\}\).

When you linearise the flow \(\Phi_t\) around the orbit through \(x\), the perturbation evolves by the **variational (tangent‐linear) equation**

\[
\dot v(t)=Df\!\bigl(\Phi_t(x)\bigr)\,v(t),\qquad v(0)=v,
\]

and the solution is exactly

\[
v(t)=D\Phi_t(x)\,v.
\]

---

### Geometric meaning

* Start two trajectories: one at \(x\) and one at \(x+\varepsilon v\) with \(\varepsilon\ll1\).
* After time \(t\) their separation is \(\varepsilon\,D\Phi_t(x)v + O(\varepsilon^{2})\).
* The Lyapunov exponent

  \[
    \lambda(x,v)=\lim_{t\to\infty}\frac1t\log\|D\Phi_t(x)v\|
  \]

  tells you the **average exponential rate** at which that infinitesimal separation grows (or shrinks).

Different initial directions \(v\) can converge to different growth rates; Oseledets’ theorem organises all such directions into invariant subspaces \(E_i(x)\) where every non-zero \(v\in E_i(x)\) has the same exponent \(\lambda_i\).

---

### Practical/numerical note

When you run the Benettin or QR algorithm you start with an orthonormal set of perturbation vectors \(v^{(1)},\dots,v^{(k)}\).  Re-orthonormalising each step keeps them from coalescing into the most unstable direction and lets you extract the whole spectrum \(\lambda_1\ge\dots\ge\lambda_k\).

So **\(v\)** is nothing exotic: it is just “a small displacement of the initial state”, treated infinitesimally so that the linearisation \(D\Phi_t(x)\) is the correct first-order description of how that displacement evolves.
how do I get the characteristic ones?

thoughts.content: It seems like the user is asking about how to calculate the "characteristic ones." Based on the context, they might be referring to the Lyapunov exponents or characteristic exponents in dynamical systems, where "characteristic" is used as another naming convention for these exponents. They could also be asking how to compute these exponents for specific characteristic directions in a system, or possibly referencing the original concept introduced by Lyapunov or Poincaré. Let me walk through a clear explanation on how to compute them.

parts:
### What “the characteristic ones” means  
Historically *characteristic exponents* ≡ Lyapunov exponents.  The word “characteristic” simply stresses that the limits
\[
\lambda_{1}>\lambda_{2}>\dots>\lambda_{k},\qquad 
k\le n,
\]
are intrinsic (characteristic) numbers of the flow—independent of coordinates or of which tangent vectors you start with, once the Oseledec limits have been taken.  So “get the characteristic ones” = “compute (or prove the existence of) the full Lyapunov spectrum”.

Below are the two standard routes:

---

## 1 The theoretical formula  
For any \(C^{1}\) flow \(\Phi_{t}\) on \(\mathbb R^{n}\) possessing a compact invariant set \(A\) (your global attractor) and an invariant probability measure \(\mu\) with  
\(\displaystyle\int\!\log^{+}\|Df\|\,d\mu<\infty,\)
Oseledets’ multiplicative-ergodic theorem gives, for \(\mu\)-a.e.\ \(x\),  

\[
\boxed{\;
\lambda_i(x)=\;\lim_{t\to\infty}\frac1t\log\sigma_i\!\bigl(D\Phi_t(x)\bigr)
\;},\qquad i=1,\dots,n,
\]

where \(\sigma_1\ge\dots\ge\sigma_n>0\) are the singular values of the fundamental matrix \(D\Phi_t(x)\).  

*If \(\mu\) is ergodic, the \(\lambda_i(x)\) are independent of \(x\) and you write simply \(\lambda_i\).*

---

## 2 How to **compute** the characteristic exponents

### Benettin–Shimada–Wolf QR method (continuous time)

1. **Choose an initial point** \(x_0\) in (or near) the attractor and an orthonormal frame \(V_0=[v^{(1)}_0,\dots,v^{(n)}_0]\) of tangent vectors.  
2. **Integrate** simultaneously  
   \[
     \dot x = f(x), \qquad
     \dot V = Df(x)\,V ,
   \]
   over a short step \(\Delta t\).  
3. **QR-orthonormalise**: \(V = QR\) with \(Q\) orthonormal, \(R\) upper-triangular.  
   Store the diagonal \(r_{ii}\).  Replace \(V\gets Q\).  
4. **Accumulate logarithms**:  
   \[
     S_i(k)=\sum_{j=1}^{k}\log r_{ii}(j),\qquad
     \widehat\lambda_i(k)=\frac{S_i(k)}{k\,\Delta t}.
   \]
5. Repeat steps 2–4 for \(k=1,\dots,K\) until \(\widehat\lambda_i(k)\) stabilise.

The ordered set \(\widehat\lambda_1\ge\dots\ge\widehat\lambda_n\) converges to the characteristic Lyapunov exponents.

**Why it works:** QR at each step extracts the current singular-value factors of \(D\Phi_{\Delta t}\); summing the logarithms reproduces the time-log-singular-value formula, while keeping all tangent directions numerically orthogonal.

---

### Covariant Lyapunov Vectors (Ginelli et al. 2007) – if you also need the characteristic directions

1. **Forward pass:** run the QR algorithm above and store the \(R\)-matrices (or their diagonals and off-diagonals) along the trajectory.  
2. **Backward pass:** starting from \(t=t_K\) set \(C_K=Q_K\) and iterate backwards  
   \[
     C_{k-1}=R_k^{-1}C_k
   \]
   followed by column-normalisation.  Columns of each \(C_k\) converge to the covariant Lyapunov vectors \(e^{(i)}(x_k)\).  
3. The exponents are the same \(\lambda_i\) already found; the vectors now give the invariant splitting \(T_{x_k}\mathbb R^{n}=E_1\oplus\cdots\oplus E_k\).

---

### Special cases / shortcuts

* **Gradient flows** (\(f=-\nabla U\)): every orbit ends at an equilibrium ⇒ exponents equal the real parts of the Jacobian eigenvalues at that equilibrium.  
* **Hamiltonian flows**: exponents occur in symmetric pairs \((+\lambda,-\lambda)\) plus zeros; exploit symplectic structure to halve the computation.  
* **Time-\(1\) Poincaré map**: for periodic orbits, Lyapunov exponents = logarithms of Floquet multipliers divided by the period.

---

### Numerical good practices

1. Use adaptive integrators for both \(x\) and tangent equations so that the same \(\Delta t\) is applied to \(x\) and \(V\).  
2. Ensure **double precision** or higher, because exponent differences can span many orders of magnitude.  
3. Discard a transient so that the base trajectory is already near the attractor before starting accumulation.  
4. Monitor the running sums \(S_i(k)\); convergence is geometric and the slowest rate is governed by the gap \(|\lambda_i-\lambda_{i+1}|\).

---

### References to cite for the “characteristic” definition

* V. I. Oseledets, *Tr. Moscow Math. Soc.* 19 (1968) – theorem in singular-value form.  
* G. Benettin, L. Galgani, A. Giorgilli, J-M. Strelcyn, *Meccanica* 15 (1980) – QR algorithm.  
* F. Ginelli et al., *Phys. Rev. Lett.* 99 (2007) – covariant Lyapunov vectors.

---

**Bottom line:**  
The *characteristic* Lyapunov exponents are the limits of \(t^{-1}\log\sigma_i(D\Phi_t)\).  In practice you “get” them by integrating the tangent flow and repeatedly orthonormalising (QR) to peel off the singular-value growth factors; the accumulated averages converge to the desired numbers.

parts:
# Kaplan–Yorke Dimension and Information Dimension in Dynamical Systems: A Literature Review

## Background and Definitions

**Kaplan–Yorke (KY) Dimension:** The Kaplan–Yorke dimension (also known as the Lyapunov dimension) is a number derived from the Lyapunov exponents of a dynamical system. Given Lyapunov exponents $\lambda_1 \ge \lambda_2 \ge \cdots \ge \lambda_n$, one defines $j$ as the largest index such that the sum $\sum_{i=1}^j \lambda_i$ is non-negative, while $\sum_{i=1}^{j+1} \lambda_i$ is negative【3†L118-L126】. The KY dimension is then defined by interpolating to the point where the sum of exponents changes sign【23†L32-L40】:

\[ D_{KY} \;=\; j \;+\; \frac{\sum_{i=1}^j \lambda_i}{|\lambda_{j+1}|}\,. \]

This formula, introduced by Kaplan and Yorke in 1979, provides an **estimate** of the fractal dimension of a strange attractor【23†L9-L17】【3†L128-L136】. It is sometimes called the *Lyapunov dimension*. Crucially, the KY dimension can be computed from time-series data or equations via the Lyapunov spectrum, making it a practical tool for high-dimensional systems where direct fractal dimension calculations are difficult.

**Information Dimension:** The information dimension $D_{1}$ is one of the classical fractal dimension definitions (alongside the Hausdorff, box-counting, and correlation dimensions). For an invariant measure $\mu$ on the attractor, the information dimension quantifies how the measure scales in small neighborhoods. Intuitively, $D_{1}$ measures the scaling of the Shannon information needed to specify a point on the attractor at a given resolution. Formally, if the attractor is covered by boxes of size $\epsilon$, and $p_i(\epsilon)$ is the probability mass of the $i$th box, then $D_{1}$ is defined by $D_{1} = \lim_{\epsilon\to 0} \frac{-\sum_i p_i(\epsilon)\log p_i(\epsilon)}{\log \epsilon^{-1}}$. This definition makes $D_{1}$ sensitive to how *non-uniform* the invariant measure is on the attractor. In particular, $D_{1}$ equals the *Hausdorff (or capacity) dimension* if the measure is uniformly distributed, but in general $D_{1}$ can be smaller than the geometric (Hausdorff) dimension for multifractal attractors. Practically, the information dimension is often very close to the **correlation dimension** $D_{2}$ for typical chaotic attractors【18†L7-L10】, and indeed many studies use correlation dimension as an approximation to $D_{1}$ when analyzing experimental data.

**Relationship Question:** The central question is whether the KY dimension (a Lyapunov-based estimate) matches the actual information dimension of the invariant measure on an attractor. If they are equal, one could compute a system’s fractal dimension directly from Lyapunov exponents, an extremely useful simplification. This is encapsulated in the **Kaplan–Yorke conjecture**, which posits that *for a typical chaotic dynamical system with a physical invariant measure, the KY dimension equals the information dimension of the attractor*【21†L5-L13】. In other words, knowing the Lyapunov spectrum would give the “true” fractal dimension of the attractor’s natural measure【19†L207-L216】. Below we review the development of this conjecture and the evidence for or against it, focusing on literature since 2000 while including key earlier results for context.

## The Kaplan–Yorke Conjecture and Early Insights

When Kaplan and Yorke first proposed their dimension formula in 1979, they checked it on a two-dimensional map and conjectured that it gives the correct capacity (box-counting) dimension【29†L29-L38】. This was subsequently proven for certain 2D systems by 1982【29†L37-L45】. A few years later, Frederickson *et al.* (1983) broadened the conjecture, suggesting that the KY dimension is *generically equal* to the “probabilistic” dimension of the attractor’s natural measure – which in practice appears to be the information dimension【29†L39-L45】. In other words, they conjectured $D_{KY} = D_{1}$ for typical chaotic attractors. Early numerical studies provided supporting evidence: for example, Frederickson *et al.* computed KY dimensions and fractal dimensions for several strange attractors and found them in close agreement【23†L9-L14】. Around the same time, Eckmann and Ruelle’s influential 1985 review noted that various definitions of dimension (Hausdorff, information, correlation, etc.) often coincide for strange attractors, bolstering the plausibility of the conjectured equality in practice【29†L39-L45】.

On the theoretical side, **partial rigorous results** were obtained in the 1980s. F. Ledrappier and L.-S. Young developed formulas linking Lyapunov exponents, entropy, and dimension for invariant measures on attractors. In particular, Ledrappier (1981) proved that the KY dimension provides an **upper bound** on the information dimension for any ergodic invariant measure of a $C^2$ map【29†L39-L45】. In formula form, one always has $D_{1} \le D_{KY}$【18†L13-L16】. This important result means the conjecture (equality) *cannot* fail by KY underestimating the dimension – if it fails, KY is an overestimate. Further work by Ledrappier and Young (1985, 1988) gave exact dimension formulas for certain systems. Notably, they showed that under strong hyperbolicity conditions (such as *Axiom A attractors* with Sinai–Ruelle–Bowen (SRB) measures), the information dimension can be expressed in terms of Lyapunov exponents and measure-theoretic entropy. In such cases the KY formula indeed holds exactly【28†L1-L4】. For example, Young (1982) proved the conjecture for $C^2$ diffeomorphisms on surfaces with an SRB measure【28†L1-L4】. In fact, for some low-dimensional cases where the chaotic attractor has a smooth invariant measure on unstable manifolds (e.g. certain invertible 2D maps), one can show that **all common fractal dimensions coincide** (Hausdorff = information = correlation dimension)【29†L39-L45】. These rigorous results provided early confirmation that $D_{KY}=D_{1}$ in well-behaved (uniformly hyperbolic) scenarios.

However, even in the early period researchers were aware of **counterexamples** where the KY conjecture breaks down. A classic example is the Feigenbaum attractor at the onset of chaos (the period-doubling accumulation point). This attractor has a Lyapunov exponent of zero, and its fractal dimension is not predicted by the KY formula; indeed, it was cited as a case where the conjecture is “false”【18†L7-L10】. Another simple counterexample is an invariant measure supported on a periodic orbit: the KY formula would yield a non-integer value (based on the positive Lyapunov exponents being zero), whereas the information dimension of a periodic orbit is 0 (a delta measure). Such examples are *nongeneric*, but they illustrate that without additional assumptions (like an ergodic chaotic measure with broad support), $D_{KY}$ need not equal $D_{1}$. In particular, if an attractor’s invariant measure is singular in the unstable directions (not fully exploring them), the actual information dimension will fall short of the KY interpolation. By the late 1990s, the consensus was that the Kaplan–Yorke conjecture is **unproven in general** but widely believed to hold for “typical” chaotic attractors【21†L5-L13】. It remained a useful heuristic: KY gives a convenient estimate of attractor dimension that in practice is often close to measured values【23†L9-L14】, with $D_{KY}$ always providing an upper bound【18†L13-L16】.

## Rigorous Results and Theory (2000–Present)

In the 21st century, mathematicians have further examined the KY conjecture, aiming to clarify *when* and *why* equality $D_{KY}=D_{1}$ should hold. While a general proof is still elusive, several **conditional and partial results** have emerged. One line of research has been to identify structural conditions on the dynamical system that guarantee the KY formula’s validity. As noted above, if the system has an SRB (physical) measure that is sufficiently “nice” (e.g. yields positive entropy equal to the sum of positive Lyapunov exponents, and has no pathological clustering of measure in phase space), then one expects $D_{1}=D_{KY}$. Barreira and Pesin (e.g. 2001) and others in the dynamical systems community have advanced the theory of dimension for invariant measures, giving criteria for when the Lyapunov dimension matches various fractal dimensions. For instance, in random dynamical systems or certain parametrized families of maps, it has been shown that the KY conjecture holds **almost surely** or for "prevalent" choices of parameters【28†L1-L4】. These works solidify the idea that *generically* (in a measure-theoretic sense) the KY formula is correct, whereas failures tend to be linked to special symmetries or degeneracies.

A notable recent theoretical study by Gröger and Hunt (2013) directly addressed the question of genericity in the KY conjecture【21†L5-L13】. They investigated two coupled "skinny Baker’s maps" – a class of model systems that can be tuned to have either coupled or decoupled chaotic dynamics. In the fully decoupled case, the attractor’s information dimension is strictly less than the KY dimension (essentially two independent subsystems, each contributing to KY sum but not fully utilized by the joint measure). Gröger and Hunt then asked: does *coupling* restore the equality? They proved that if the two subsystems are coupled in one direction (one drives the other), the dimensions **remain unequal for all coupling functions** in that configuration【21†L9-L16】. This provides an example of a robust violation of the KY conjecture in a skew-product system. Conversely, for coupling in the opposite direction, they showed that $D_{1}=D_{KY}$ for a “prevalent” (essentially generic) set of coupling functions【21†L11-L18】. In other words, when the coupling is applied in a way that lets both subsystems’ expansions mix, almost any generic coupling will cause the information dimension to coincide with the Lyapunov dimension. These results support a nuanced view: **most typical interactions lead to KY equality, but there are classes of systems (notably some uni-directionally coupled or skew-product systems) where the KY dimension can robustly overestimate the information dimension**【21†L15-L22】. The authors conjectured that in higher-dimensional skew-product systems, such persistent differences might occur more generally, whereas in fully interacting systems the conjecture should usually hold【21†L17-L22】.

Another avenue of theoretical progress has been extending dimension formulas to broader contexts. For example, in invariant measures that are *not* SRB (singular measures concentrated on fractal repellers or strange attractors without smooth structure), new techniques have been developed to compute or bound $D_{1}$. These often combine Lyapunov exponents with additional information about measure distribution (for instance, conditional measures on stable manifolds). While these approaches reinforce that $D_{1}\le D_{KY}$ generally, they also show how $D_{1}$ can fall short of $D_{KY}$ depending on entropy deficiency or multi-fractal behavior. In summary, the past two decades of theory have not produced a simple universal criterion to guarantee $D_{KY}=D1$ beyond the classical hyperbolic cases, but they have **sharpened our understanding of why the conjecture works “almost” always and where it breaks**. The current theoretical consensus is that the KY conjecture is true for broad classes of systems that are mixing and ergodic (indeed it has been rigorously *proved for some specific classes* of dynamical systems【28†L1-L4】), but one must be cautious of certain structural exceptions.

## Numerical and Experimental Findings (2000–Present)

Empirical research on chaotic systems has played a crucial role in testing the relationship between KY and information dimensions. Over the last two decades, numerous **numerical simulations and physical experiments** have compared $D_{KY}$ to measured fractal dimensions (typically $D_{2}$ or $D_{1}$) of attractors:

- **Experiments Confirming KY Predictions:** A 2003 study by Nichols *et al.* demonstrated the conjecture in a laboratory setting by constructing an apparatus with a *controllable attractor dimension*. They drove a mechanical system (a steel plate) with a chaotic input signal and actively adjusted the Lyapunov exponents of the driving signal. The result was an experimental attractor whose dimension they could vary. The observed fractal dimensions of the plate’s response closely tracked the KY formula’s predictions, across a range from low-dimensional to higher-dimensional chaos【16†L175-L183】. The authors reported *“excellent agreement”* between KY-predicted dimensions and those measured from data【19†L223-L232】【16†L175-L183】, lending strong support to the conjecture in real-world systems. This work, along with prior experimental studies on lasers and fluid turbulence, solidified the practical utility of KY: even when not rigorously guaranteed, the KY dimension often matches the attractor’s true dimension within measurement error【19†L213-L221】【19†L215-L223】.

- **Widespread Numerical Evidence:**  It has become common in chaos analysis to compute both Lyapunov exponents and correlation dimension from a time series as a consistency check【19†L213-L221】. In most cases (e.g. the Lorenz system, the Rössler system, Hénon and other standard chaotic attractors), researchers find that $D_{KY}$ is *very close* to the dimension estimated by data methods like Grassberger–Procaccia algorithm (which approximates $D_{2}$). For example, J. C. Sprott and colleagues performed systematic comparisons in the 2000s between correlation dimensions and KY dimensions for a variety of chaotic systems【24†L130-L139】【24†L157-L162】. They observed that $D_{KY}$ generally lies slightly above $D_{2}$ (as expected from the $D_{1}\ge D_{2}$ inequality), but often by a small margin, and the two tend to converge as one gets more complete data【24†L157-L162】. In their extensive computations, no large discrepancies were found for typical chaotic attractors; the KY estimate was usually within a few percent of the measured fractal dimension. This aligns with earlier observations that KY is an effective estimator: *“the Kaplan–Yorke dimension is close to other dimensions such as the box-counting, information, and correlation dimensions for typical strange attractors”*【23†L9-L14】.

- **Identifying Exceptions:** Despite the general agreement, researchers have actively looked for (and found) cases where $D_{KY} \neq D_{1}$. One class of systems attracting attention involves **nonequilibrium steady states in dissipative systems** (often studied in statistical physics). In the late 1990s, Posch and Hoover examined chaotic particle systems with thermostats (modeling nonequilibrium fluids) and found that the KY dimension did not match the capacity dimension in some instances【8†L40-L47】. More recently, W. G. Hoover and coworkers revisited the Baker map — a simple chaotic mapping — in a compressible (dissipative) form. In principle, the Baker map is a textbook hyperbolic system, and many expected it to satisfy the KY conjecture exactly. However, Hoover *et al.* reported **consistent differences** between $D_{KY}$ and direct computations of $D_{1}$ for certain “skinny” Baker map variants【8†L40-L47】. In a 2023 study, they showed that for some 4D flows (related to Gaussian thermostat systems), the KY formula overestimates the pointwise information dimension by a noticeable amount【8†L40-L47】【8†L42-L49】. In fact, they found the pointwise dimensions to vary in an unexpected way with the scale resolution, deviating from the KY prediction. Such findings indicate that in these specialized systems, the attractor’s measure has structure that causes $D_{1}$ to be lower than the idealized KY value.

- **Quantifying the Discrepancies:** A striking example of these discrepancies is given by Hoover’s 2020 *Ian Snook Prize* problem, which challenged researchers to reconcile three different estimates of the information dimension for a stochastic random walk (equivalent to a 2D Baker map). The three methods – (1) a Cantor-set-like construction, (2) direct mesh-based computation from simulation data, and (3) the KY Lyapunov dimension – yielded values $D_{1} \approx 0.734$, $0.7415$, and $0.7897$ respectively【7†L57-L65】. The KY route gave the highest estimate, while two independent direct methods gave slightly lower values. Notably, **no clear explanation** for the divergence (about 5-7% in this case) has yet been found【7†L59-L67】. This illustrates that even for simple, low-dimensional chaotic models, subtle effects can cause the KY conjecture to *almost* hold but not exactly. The differences, albeit small, are robust and reproducible in these cases. Such results have spurred continued investigation. Are these discrepancies due to finite data and convergence issues, or do they reflect true theoretical differences? Current evidence leans toward the latter – for the Baker map family, the disagreement between $D_{KY}$ and $D_{1}$ seems to persist even with extremely large data sets and careful analysis【8†L40-L47】.

In summary, the bulk of numerical and experimental studies post-2000 support the idea that $D_{KY}$ is a **reliable predictor** of the information dimension for most chaotic systems. Many experiments (mechanical, optical, fluid) have found KY’s prediction to be within experimental uncertainty of the measured fractal dimension【19†L213-L221】【16†L175-L183】. At the same time, targeted studies on pathological or finely tuned systems (like skew-product maps or certain nonequilibrium attractors) have unveiled small but definite violations of the conjecture. These counterexamples are valuable because they highlight the conditions under which the KY formula can fail – typically when the invariant measure has an extreme non-uniformity or the dynamical splitting prevents full mixing of degrees of freedom.

## Conclusion: Current Understanding of the $D_{KY}$–$D_{1}$ Relationship

**Equality vs. Inequality:** As of 2025, the precise relationship between the Kaplan–Yorke dimension and the information dimension remains an open question in general. No universal proof guarantees $D_{KY} = D_{1}$ for all dynamical systems, and indeed **known counterexamples** show that strict equality need not hold in every case【18†L7-L10】. What has been established rigorously is a one-sided relationship: the information dimension of any invariant measure cannot exceed the Kaplan–Yorke (Lyapunov) dimension【18†L13-L16】. In practice this often manifests as $D_{1}$ being **very close or equal** to $D_{KY}$ for “typical” chaotic attractors, especially those with an SRB (physical) measure and strong mixing properties. Extensive empirical evidence and some theory suggest that *for most chaotic systems of interest, $D_{KY}$ and $D_{1}$ coincide within measurement accuracy*. However, when the invariant measure is highly singular or the dynamics have a special structure (e.g. certain partially decoupled subsystems), $D_{1}$ can fall noticeably below $D_{KY}$. In those cases the KY conjecture fails, although the gap is usually modest (a few percent in reported studies)【7†L59-L67】. In summary, the Kaplan–Yorke dimension provides an **upper bound** and often an excellent approximation to the information dimension of an attractor【18†L13-L16】. Equality can be regarded as proven under certain conditions (uniform hyperbolicity or genericity assumptions)【28†L1-L4】, and it appears to be the rule rather than the exception in natural chaotic systems. Yet no single formula or theorem applies in full generality – the relationship is not *unconditionally exact*. Ongoing research aims to refine the conditions for equality and understand the small deviations observed in special cases, keeping the Kaplan–Yorke conjecture as an important guiding principle in the study of fractal dimensions of dynamical systems.

**Sources:**

- Kaplan & Yorke (1979); Frederickson *et al.* (1983) – original formulation of the conjecture【29†L39-L45】.  
- Ledrappier & Young (1985, 1988) – rigorous dimension formulas and $D_{1}\le D_{KY}$ proof【29†L39-L45】.  
- Eckmann & Ruelle (1985) – review of fractal dimensions in chaos (noting typical coincidences and exceptions)【18†L7-L10】【29†L39-L45】.  
- Young (1982) – proof of KY conjecture for certain 2D diffeomorphisms【28†L1-L4】.  
- Nichols *et al.* (2003) – experimental verification of $D_{KY}=D_{1}$ in a controllable system【19†L223-L232】【16†L175-L183】.  
- Chlouverakis & Sprott (2005) – numerical comparison of Lyapunov (KY) and correlation dimensions across systems【24†L157-L162】【23†L9-L14】.  
- Gröger & Hunt (2013) – analysis of coupled Baker’s maps showing generic validity and robust failure scenarios for the conjecture【21†L9-L17】.  
- Hoover *et al.* (2023) – findings of measurable deviations between KY and information dimensions in certain flows and maps【8†L40-L47】.  
- Hoover (2019) – Snook Prize problem highlighting unexplained differences in $D_{1}$ estimation methods【7†L59-L67】.

metadata.text: This work offers strong experimental evidence of a conjectured relationship between LEs and fractal dimension. The Kaplan–Yorke conjecture (11 ) states that a system's complete Lyapunov spectrum may be used to give direct estimates of a system's fractal dimension (specifically, information dimension), implying that knowledge of one quantity can lead to estimates of the other. Although the conjecture has been shown to be false in certain instances, it remains a useful and widely used tool in the analysis of nonlinear system dynamics. For numerically generated data, the relationship is routinely invoked ( 33–14 ) while experimental agreement has been observed for laser data ( 35), a mechanical oscillator (16), and in fluid mechanics

metadata.text: develop an experimental system with controllable dimension by making use of the Kaplan–Yorke conjecture. A rectangular steel plate is driven with the output of a chaotic oscillator. We controlled the Lyapunov exponents of the driving and then computed the fractal dimension of the plate's response. The Kaplan–Yorke relationship predicted the system's dimension extremely well. This finding strongly suggests that other driven linear systems will behave similarly. The ability to control the dimension of a structure's vibrational response is important in the field of vibration-based structural health monitoring for the robust extraction of damage-sensitive features.

metadata.title: Improved Kaplan-Yorke Dimension
metadata.text: J. Kaplan and J. A. Yorke [Springer Lecture Notes in Mathematics 730, 204 (1979)] have conjectured that the dimension of a strange attractor can be approximated from the spectrum of Lyapunov exponents.  Such a dimension has been called the Kaplan-Yorke (or Lyapunov) dimension, and it has been shown that this dimension is close to other dimensions such as the box-counting, information, and correlation dimensions for typical strange attractors.

metadata.title: Information Dimensions of Simple Four-Dimensional Flows | CMST
metadata.text: > Baker Maps have long served as pedagogical tools for understanding chaos and fractal phase-space distributions. Recent work [1], following earlier efforts from 1997 [2], shows that the Kaplan-Yorke formula for information dimension disagrees with direct computation for some simple compressible Baker Maps. Here we extend this map work to simple continuous flows. metadata.title: [1910.12642] 2020 Ian Snook Prize Problem : Three Routes to the Information Dimensions for a One-Dimensional Stochastic Random Walk and for an Equivalent Prototypical Two-Dimensional Baker Map
metadata.text: Map and an equivalent stochastic random walk. The two-dimensional deterministic, time-reversible, chaotic, fractal, and dissipative Baker map is equivalent to the stochastic one-dimensional random walk model for which three distinct estimates for the information dimension, $\{ \ 0.7897,\ 0.741_5, \ 0.7337 \ \}$ have all been put forward. So far there is no cogent explanation for the differences among them. We describe the three routes to the information dimension, $D_I$: [ 1 ] iterated Cantor-like mappings, [ 2 ] mesh-based analyses of single-point iterations, and [ 3 ] the Kaplan-Yorke Lyapunov dimension, thought by many to be exact for these models. metadata.text: and widely used tool in the analysis of nonlinear system dynamics. For numerically generated data, the relationship is routinely invoked (12 – 34) while experimental agreement has been observed for laser data (15 ), a mechanical oscillator ( 36), and in fluid mechanics (Taylor–Couette flow) (17). In each of the above cited works, the Kaplan–Yorke conjecture was used as a check between estimates of LEs and dimension.

metadata.title: Controlling system dimension: A class of real systems that obey the Kaplan–Yorke conjecture - PMC
metadata.text: develop an experimental system with controllable dimension by making use of the Kaplan–Yorke conjecture. A rectangular steel plate is driven with the output of a chaotic oscillator. We controlled the Lyapunov exponents of the driving and then computed the fractal dimension of the plate's response. The Kaplan–Yorke relationship predicted the system's dimension extremely well. This finding strongly suggests that other driven linear systems will behave similarly. The ability to control the dimension of a structure's vibrational response is important in the field of vibration-based structural health monitoring for the robust extraction of damage-sensitive features.

February 2013 The Kaplan-Yorke conjecture states that for “typical” dynamical systems with a physical measure, the information dimension and the Lyapunov dimension coincide. We explore this conjecture in a neighborhood of a system for which the two dimensions do not coincide because the system consists of two uncoupled subsystems. We are interested in whether coupling “typically” restores the equality of the dimensions. The particular subsystems we consider are skinny baker’s maps, and we consider uni-directional coupling. content_references.title: Controlling system dimension: A class of real systems that obey the Kaplan–Yorke conjecture - PMC
content_references.snippet: This work offers strong experimental evidence of a conjectured relationship between LEs and fractal dimension. The Kaplan–Yorke conjecture (11 ) states that a system's complete Lyapunov spectrum may be used to give direct estimates of a system's fractal dimension (specifically, information dimension), implying that knowledge of one quantity can lead to estimates of the other. Although the conjecture has been shown to be false in certain instances, it remains a useful and widely used tool in the analysis of nonlinear system dynamics. For numerically generated data, the relationship is routinely invoked ( 33–14 ) while experimental agreement has been observed for laser data ( 35), a mechanical oscillator (16), and in fluid mechanics

The ability to control the dimension of a structure's vibrational response is important in the field of vibration-based structural health monitoring for the robust extraction of damage-sensitive features.
